dt: {bc}the first day of the ancient Roman month from which days were counted backward to the ides

et: Middle English {it}kalendis{/it} "first day of the month," borrowed from Latin {it}kalendae, calendae,{/it} plural noun, probably from an irregularly formed gerundive of {it}calāre{/it} "to announce, proclaim" {ma}{mat|low:3|low:3}{/ma}

Latin {it}kalendae{/it} was one of a small number of words in which an earlier spelling with {it}k{/it} was retained in later republican and imperial Rome. The origin of {it}kalendae{/it} was thus explained by M. Terentius {et_link|varro|Varro:b} in {it}De lingua latina{/it}: "Primi dies mensium nominati Kalendae, quod his diebus calantur eius mensis Nonae a pontificibus, quintanae an septimanae sint futurae, in Capitolio in Curia Calabra sic: 'Die te quinti kalo Iuno Covella'…." ("The first days of the months are called Kalendae, because on these days the Nones of that month are announced [{it}calantur{/it}] by the pontifexes—whether they would be on the fifth or seventh days—in the Curia Calabra [a sacred area where the new moon was observed] on the Capitoline Hill, in the following way: 'Juno Covella, I announce [{it}calō{/it}] you on the fifth day'….") The form {it}kalendae{/it} for expected {it}kalandae{/it} has been variously explained; it may be a retention of an earlier conjugation {it}*calere{/it} or {it}*calēre{/it} (which would accord with Umbrian {it}kařetu{/it}—see note at {et_link|low:3|low:3}).
shortdef: the first day of the ancient Roman month from which days were counted backward to the ides

dt: {bc}an acute inflammatory illness involving blood vessels throughout the body that is of unknown cause and chiefly affects infants and children

Kawasaki disease is characterized especially by fever, redness and swelling of the hands and feet (often followed by peeling of the skin), {d_link|conjunctivitis|conjunctivitis}, a reddish rash typically on the abdomen and groin, inflammation of mucous membranes (as of the tongue and throat), and swollen lymph nodes in the neck. It may progress to sometimes life-threatening inflammation of heart muscle and coronary artery damage, such as bulging and thinning of the artery walls.

dt.t: The high fever, rash, red lips and palms, and swollen lymph nodes pointed to another condition—{wi}Kawasaki disease{/wi}. First identified in Japan in 1967, {wi}Kawasaki{/wi} strikes more than 2,000 U.S. children annually, 80 percent of them under age five.

The most serious complications of {wi}Kawasaki disease{/wi} involve the coronary vessels and the heart. About 14% to 30% of the affected cases have been shown to develop coronary aneurysms, resulting in acute myocardial infarction in some cases, and death may occur in 2%.

By nightfall the boy was started on a high dose of aspirin and {d_link|IVIG|IVIG}, an infusion containing antibodies collected from thousands of blood donors, the first-line treatment for {wi}Kawasaki disease{/wi}.

shortdef: an acute inflammatory illness involving blood vessels throughout the body that is of unknown cause and chiefly affects infants and children —abbreviation KD—called also mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome

dt: {bc}a whole wheel or ball of cheese

et: early Scots {it}cabok, kebboc{/it} "a cheese," of uncertain origin

Especially in early Scots, {it}cabok,{/it} etc. is usually used as a count noun with an appended genitive ({it}kebboc of cheis, cabok of cheis{/it}). The word has been compared with Scottish Gaelic {it}càbag{/it} in the same sense, attested since the 18th century, but the latter is most likely a borrowing from Scots. According to the {it}Scottish National Dictionary,{/it} {it}ceapag{/it} is recorded in modern Scottish Gaelic dialects in the sense "a round lump, as of cheese," apparently an extended meaning from the senses "wheel of a wheelbarrow, small pair of stocks, small turf or sod, block" (from Edward Dwelly's early-20th-century dictionary), a diminutive of {it}ceap{/it} "block, stock," a word common to Scottish Gaelic and Irish (Middle Irish {it}cep{/it}). But the "lump of cheese" sense, not known before the 20th century, may again be a reflection of the Scots word.
shortdef: a whole wheel or ball of cheese

dt: {bc}to move (a ship) by means of a line attached to a small anchor dropped at the distance and in the direction desired

et: perhaps variant of {it}cadge{/it} "to fasten, tie," going back to Middle English {it}caggen,{/it} of obscure origin

Though the variation in vowel between {it}kedge{/it} and {it}cadge{/it} is unremarkable (compare \kech\ as an alternate pronunciation of \kach\ for {et_link|catch:1|catch:1}), evidence for the existence of {it}cadge{/it} is exiguous, the best example being an isolated record of the word in 18th-century Lancashire (in Francis Grose, {it}A Provincial Glossary,{/it} 2nd edition, 1790). Middle English {it}caggen{/it} is equally problematic, as the meaning of none of the five citations in the Middle English Dictionary is certain; the variation of forms in the manuscripts of the {it}Siege of Jerusalem{/it} and {it}Wars of Alexander{/it} suggests that the copyists were likewise unsure of the word's identity. There is no likely relation with early Scots {it}cagger, cadgear{/it} "itinerant dealer in fish or other goods" (see {et_link|cadge|cadge}).
shortdef: to move (a ship) by means of a line attached to a small anchor dropped at the distance and in the direction desired
to move a ship by kedging
a small anchor used especially in kedging

pt: {sc}level{/sc} {sc}flat{/sc} {sc}plane{/sc} {sc}even{/sc} {sc}smooth{/sc} mean having a surface without bends, curves, or irregularities. {sc}level{/sc} applies to a horizontal surface that lies on a line parallel with the horizon.
{sc}flat{/sc} applies to a surface devoid of noticeable curvatures, prominences, or depressions.
{sc}plane{/sc} applies to any real or imaginary flat surface in which a straight line between any two points on it lies wholly within that surface.
{sc}even{/sc} applies to a surface that is noticeably flat or level or to a line that is observably straight.

pt.t: trim the hedge so it is {it}even{/it}

pt: {sc}smooth{/sc} applies especially to a polished surface free of irregularities.
{sc}steady{/sc} {sc}even{/sc} {sc}equable{/sc} mean not varying throughout a course or extent. {sc}steady{/sc} implies lack of fluctuation or interruption of movement.
{sc}even{/sc} suggests a lack of variation in quality or character.
{sc}equable{/sc} implies lack of extremes or of sudden sharp changes.

et: Middle English, from Old English {it}efen{/it}; akin to Old High German {it}eban{/it} even
shortdef: having a horizontal surface : flat

dt: {bc}intellectually alert {bc}having or characteristic of a quick penetrating mind

pt: {sc}sharp{/sc} {sc}keen{/sc} {sc}acute{/sc} mean having or showing alert competence and clear understanding. {sc}sharp{/sc} implies quick perception, clever resourcefulness, or sometimes questionable trickiness.

pt.t: {it}sharp{/it} enough to spot a confidence game

pt: {sc}keen{/sc} suggests quickness, enthusiasm, and a penetrating mind.

pt.t: a {it}keen{/it} observer of the political scene

pt: {sc}acute{/sc} implies a power to penetrate and may suggest subtlety and sharpness of discrimination.

{sc}eager{/sc} {sc}avid{/sc} {sc}keen{/sc} {sc}anxious{/sc} {sc}athirst{/sc} mean moved by a strong and urgent desire or interest. {sc}eager{/sc} implies ardor and enthusiasm and sometimes impatience at delay or restraint.
{sc}avid{/sc} adds to {sc}eager{/sc} the implication of insatiability or greed.
{sc}keen{/sc} suggests intensity of interest and quick responsiveness in action.
{sc}anxious{/sc} emphasizes fear of frustration or failure or disappointment.

pt.t: {it}anxious{/it} not to make a social blunder

pt: {sc}athirst{/sc} stresses yearning but not necessarily readiness for action.

quotes.t: When you've been trying to remember something and you suddenly remember it, the mental pleasure is {qword}keen{/qword}.

Planting himself squarely before the two tall cowboys who were standing, he looked straight into their lean, bronzed faces. He spared a full moment for that {qword}keen{/qword} cool gaze before he spoke.
The {qword}keen{/qword} clear wind swept in on his left cheek, and as he bore on the helm so the {it}Sophie{/it} answered, quicker and more nervous than he had expected.
That he took a {qword}keen{/qword} interest in scientific navigation is indicated by his keeping a daybook or journal (which has not survived), and by making an honest effort to determine longitude.
Indeed, tobacco processors were {qword}keen{/qword} to promote variety even further by saturating and mixing the cut and spun leaf with a miscellany of spices …
But Mary wasn't {qword}keen{/qword} on braving the Athens streets alone so Magnus went instead; Mary would do a museum in the morning.

et: Middle English {it}kene{/it} brave, sharp, from Old English {it}cēne{/it} brave; akin to Old High German {it}kuoni{/it} brave
shortdef: intellectually alert : having or characteristic of a quick penetrating mind; also : shrewdly astute
extremely sensitive in perception
sharply contested

pt: {sc}keep{/sc} {sc}observe{/sc} {sc}celebrate{/sc} {sc}commemorate{/sc} mean to notice or honor a day, occasion, or deed. {sc}keep{/sc} stresses the idea of not neglecting or violating.

pt.t: {it}kept{/it} the Sabbath by refraining from work

pt: {sc}observe{/sc} suggests marking the occasion by ceremonious performance.
{sc}celebrate{/sc} suggests acknowledging an occasion by festivity.

pt.t: traditionally {it}celebrates{/it} Thanksgiving with a huge dinner

pt: {sc}commemorate{/sc} suggests that an occasion is marked by observances that remind one of the origin and significance of the event.

pt.t: {it}commemorate{/it} Memorial Day with the laying of wreaths

pt: {sc}keep{/sc} {sc}retain{/sc} {sc}detain{/sc} {sc}withhold{/sc} {sc}reserve{/sc} mean to hold in one's possession or under one's control. {sc}keep{/sc} may suggest a holding securely in one's possession, custody, or control.
{sc}retain{/sc} implies continued keeping, especially against threatened seizure or forced loss.

pt.t: managed to {it}retain{/it} their dignity even in poverty

pt: {sc}detain{/sc} suggests a delay in letting go.
{sc}withhold{/sc} implies restraint in letting go or a refusal to let go.
{sc}reserve{/sc} suggests a keeping in store for future use.

pt.t: {it}reserve{/it} some of your energy for the last mile

et: Middle English {it}kepen{/it}, from Old English {it}cēpan{/it}; perhaps akin to Old High German {it}chapfēn{/it} to look

pt: {sc}clear{/sc} {sc}transparent{/sc} {sc}translucent{/sc} {sc}limpid{/sc} mean capable of being seen through. {sc}clear{/sc} implies absence of cloudiness, haziness, or muddiness.
{sc}transparent{/sc} implies being so clear that objects can be seen distinctly.
{sc}translucent{/sc} implies the passage of light but not a clear view of what lies beyond.
{sc}limpid{/sc} suggests the soft clearness of pure water.

pt.t: her eyes were {it}limpid{/it} pools of blue

pt: {sc}clear{/sc} {sc}perspicuous{/sc} {sc}lucid{/sc} mean quickly and easily understood. {sc}clear{/sc} implies freedom from obscurity, ambiguity, or undue complexity.
{sc}perspicuous{/sc} applies to a style that is simple and elegant as well as clear.
{sc}lucid{/sc} suggests a clear logical coherence and evident order of arrangement.

et: Middle English {it}clere{/it}, from Anglo-French {it}cler{/it}, from Latin {it}clarus{/it} clear, bright; akin to Latin {it}calare{/it} to call {ma}{mat|low:3|}{/ma}

dt: {bc}any of various sulfur-containing, fibrous, acidic or basic proteins chiefly of epithelial cells and tissues that are relatively insoluble and resistant to degradation, form filaments which assemble into bundles to provide structural support, and are the primary component of hair, nails, horns, claws, hooves, quills, scales, feathers and the {d_link|epidermal|epidermal} layer of skin
In addition to its structural properties, keratin also plays a role in cell growth and proliferation, cellular transport of substances, and intercellular communication.

dt.t: Rhino horn is not actually horn but densely compacted fibers of {wi}keratin{/wi}, a protein found in hair and fingernails.
Wool fibers are composed of {wi}keratin{/wi} proteins bundled into microfibrils.

et: borrowed from German {it}Keratin,{/it} from Greek {it}kerat-,{/it} stem of {it}kéras{/it} "horn" + German {it}-in{/it} {et_link|-in:1|-in:1} {ma}{mat|kerat-|kerat-}{/ma}

The term was introduced by the German physician and chemist Johann Franz Simon (1807-43) in {it}Handbuch der angewandten medizinischen Chemie,{/it} 1. Theil, {it}Medizinisch-analytische Chemie{/it} (Berlin, 1840), p. 49.
shortdef: any of various sulfur-containing, fibrous, acidic or basic proteins chiefly of epithelial cells and tissues that are relatively insoluble and resistant to degradation, form filaments which assemble into bundles to provide structural support, and are the primary component of hair, nails, horns, claws, hooves, quills, scales, feathers and the epidermal layer of skin

dt: {bc}containing the characteristic chemical group of a ketone consisting of a carbonyl attached to two carbon atoms

dt.t: Since {wi}keto{/wi} dieting is restrictive it's a good idea to consult with your doctor before starting.

et: (sense 1) from construing of {et_link|keto-|keto-} as an adjective; (sense 2) by shortening
shortdef: of or relating to a ketone; also : containing the characteristic chemical group of a ketone consisting of a carbonyl attached to two carbon atoms
ketogenic

dt.t: Salad is great for {wi}keto{/wi}, but the dressing might not be. When in doubt, skip it.

{wi}Keto{/wi} is a diet trend that cuts out carbohydrates and sugars to stop the blood sugar from spiking and have the body enter a state of ketosis, a process in which body burns fat for energy because it does not have enough carbohydrates to burn.

shortdef: a ketogenic diet
ketone : ketone body

dt: {bc}a diet that supplies large amounts of fats, moderate amounts of proteins, and minimal amounts of carbohydrates and that is undertaken for weight loss or to control seizures in treatment-resistant epilepsy

As the body is deprived of carbohydrates in the ketogenic diet, insulin secretion drops and {d_link|glycogen|glycogen} stores in the body become depleted. The body then enters a state of nutritional {d_link|ketosis|ketosis} where {d_link|ketone bodies|ketone body} formed by the metabolism of fatty acids replace glucose as the primary energy source.

dt.t: A {wi}ketogenic diet{/wi}, says [Robert] Atkins, burns one's fat stores and uses them as a source of fuel.

The {wi}keto diet{/wi} can be restrictive and requires that you carefully measure out the various macronutrients—fat, protein and carbohydrates—to keep your body in ketosis and gain the benefits of the diet.
The center offers the latest medical and surgical treatments as well as the {wi}ketogenic diet{/wi}—a special high-fat, low-carbohydrate diet that helps control seizures in some people.

shortdef: a diet that supplies large amounts of fats, moderate amounts of proteins, and minimal amounts of carbohydrates and that is undertaken for weight loss or to control seizures in treatment-resistant epilepsy

dt: {bc}any of a class of organic compounds (such as acetone) characterized by a carbonyl group attached to two carbon atoms

et: borrowed from German {it}Keton,{/it} coinage based on {it}Aceton{/it} {et_link|acetone|acetone}

The German term {it}Keton{/it} was apparently the coinage of the chemist Leopold Gmelin (1788-1853), who introduced it in {it}Handbuch der organischen Chemie,{/it} 1. Band, 4. Auflage (Heidelberg, 1848), p. 40 passim. Gmelin characterized ketones as "Acetone im allgemeinen" ("acetones in general"), acetone being the smallest and simplest ketone.
shortdef: any of a class of organic compounds (such as acetone) characterized by a carbonyl group attached to two carbon atoms

dt: {bc}any of the three compounds acetoacetic acid, acetone, and beta-hydroxybutyric acid which are normal intermediates in lipid metabolism and accumulate in the blood and urine in abnormal amounts in conditions of impaired metabolism (such as diabetes mellitus)

dt: {bc}an abnormal increase of {d_link|ketone bodies|ketone body} in the body

et: The word {it}ketosis{/it} was apparently introduced, somewhat hesitantly, by the American physician Frederick Madison Allen (1879-1964) in "The Role of Fat in Diabetes," {it}American Journal of the Medical Sciences,{/it} series 2, vol. 153, no. 3 (March, 1917), p. 335: "The second basis of definition [of acidosis] is that of need and distinctiveness. Diminished alkalinity, increased hydrogen ion concentration, lowering of carbon dioxide, decrease of buffer salts, and (for the symptoms of these changes) acid intoxication—all these terms have definite meanings, and to appropriate the name acidosis for any one of them is merely to create a useless synonym. No other name but acidosis exists for the metabolic process which it denotes. Ketonuria and ketonemia have their accurate place but do not cover the ground. Possibly the word ketosis might be suggested and used for special purposes, but the change of established usage would be difficult and seems unnecessary."
shortdef: an abnormal increase of ketone bodies in the body

et: The word {it}ketosis{/it} was apparently introduced, somewhat hesitantly, by the American physician Frederick Madison Allen (1879-1964) in "The Role of Fat in Diabetes," {it}American Journal of the Medical Sciences,{/it} series 2, vol. 153, no. 3 (March, 1917), p. 335: "The second basis of definition [of acidosis] is that of need and distinctiveness. Diminished alkalinity, increased hydrogen ion concentration, lowering of carbon dioxide, decrease of buffer salts, and (for the symptoms of these changes) acid intoxication—all these terms have definite meanings, and to appropriate the name acidosis for any one of them is merely to create a useless synonym. No other name but acidosis exists for the metabolic process which it denotes. Ketonuria and ketonemia have their accurate place but do not cover the ground. Possibly the word ketosis might be suggested and used for special purposes, but the change of established usage would be difficult and seems unnecessary."
shortdef: an abnormal increase of ketone bodies in the body

dt: {bc}a standard English-language typewriter or computer keyboard on which the first six letters of the second row are {it}q{/it}, {it}w{/it}, {it}e{/it}, {it}r{/it}, {it}t{/it}, and {it}y{/it}

dt.t: {wi}QWERTY{/wi} may not have had the most sensible keyboard arrangement, but it had the advantage that it had been out longer than most other designs. Throughout the 1880s, typewriters with a variety of keyboard layouts were sold, but in the 1890s the market moved more and more toward {wi}QWERTY{/wi}, and by the first decade of the twentieth century it had taken over.

The {wi}QWERTY keyboard{/wi}, a central artifact of the information economy, was arranged in the 1870s with a deliberately awkward pattern of letters to slow typists down so they wouldn't jam the innards of early typing machines.

et: borrowed from Yiddish {it}kibetsn{/it} or German {it}kiebitzen{/it} "to look on (at a card game)," both borrowed from Rotwelsch (German underworld argot) {it}kiebitschen, chippischen, gippischen{/it} "(of the police) to search out, patrol," of obscure origin

In passage from Rotwelsch to ordinary vernaculars, there has presumably been a jocular transfer in sense from the undesirable observation of underworld activity by the police to observation of a more innocent activity such as a game. Corresponding to the Rotwelsch verb is a noun {it}Kiewisch, Gippisch, Kippisch,{/it} etc., "police search, investigation, patrol," attested slightly earlier, perhaps first (as {it}Gippisch, Geppisch{/it}) in a vocabulary appended to {it}Alphabetisches Verzeichnis einer Anzahl von Räubern, Dieben und Vagabonden{/it} (Hamburg, 1814), by a Danish police official, H.C. Christensen, based on an investigation carried out in Kiel in 1811-12. Neither the German or Yiddish words or their Rotwelsch source have any plausible connection to German {it}Kiebitz{/it} "lapwing" other than by secondary association.
shortdef: to act as a kibitzer
to exchange comments : chat
to observe as a kibitzer; especially : to be a kibitzer at

dt: {bc}something that serves as a check or stop
usually used in the phrase {it}put the kibosh on{/it}

dt.t: Inevitably, though, another recession will come putting the {wi}kibosh{/wi} on job and income growth …

et: A number of etymologies are summarized by Anatoly Liberman in online postings to the {it}OUPblog{/it} maintained by Oxford University Press ("Unable to put the kibosh on a hard word," May 19, 2010; "Monthly gleanings," July 28, 2010; "Three recent theories of 'kibosh'," August 14, 2013; "Etymology gleanings," November 29, 2017). The recent theories to which he alludes see the following as sources for {it}kibosh{/it}: the heraldic term {it}caboched, caboshed{/it} "(of an animal's head) borne full-face without the neck showing"; {it}kibosh{/it} as a term for an iron bar used by clogmakers in the north of England (apparently first attested in 1860); Arabic {it}kurbāj, kirbāj {/it} "whip, lash" and its source, Turkish {it}kırbaç.{/it} The latter hypothesis is argued at length in a monograph by Gerald Cohen, Stephen Goranson and Matthew Little, {it}Origin of Kibosh{/it} (Routledge, 2017), which also summarizes recently found antedatings to citations of the word in the {it}Oxford English Dictionary{/it} (dating the word with certainty to 1834, and perhaps to 1830). Pace the authors' enthusiasm, the Arabic/Turkish origin is questionable: if Charles Dickens' 1835 recording of the word as "kye-bosh" accurately reflects the vowel and accent of the first syllable (according with the current pronunciation), the phonetic gap between the source and the English word is difficult to bridge; and the authors suggest no mechanism by which an assumed loanword from the eastern Mediterranean could have found its way into the speech of lower London social strata. Liberman may well be correct that "with the present evidence at our disposal, the chance of unearthing the origin of {it}kibosh{/it} is vanishingly small."
shortdef: something that serves as a check or stop —usually used in the phrase put the kibosh on

pt: {sc}fit{/sc} {sc}suitable{/sc} {sc}meet{/sc} {sc}proper{/sc} {sc}appropriate{/sc} {sc}fitting{/sc} {sc}apt{/sc} {sc}happy{/sc}{sc}felicitous{/sc} mean right with respect to some end, need, use, or circumstance. {sc}fit{/sc} stresses adaptability and sometimes special readiness for use or action.
{sc}suitable{/sc} implies an answering to requirements or demands.
{sc}proper{/sc} suggests a suitability through essential nature or accordance with custom.
{sc}fitting{/sc} implies harmony of mood or tone.
{sc}apt{/sc} connotes a fitness marked by nicety and discrimination.
{sc}happy{/sc} suggests what is effectively or successfully appropriate.
{sc}felicitous{/sc} suggests an aptness that is opportune, telling, or graceful.

pt: {sc}kill{/sc} {sc}slay{/sc} {sc}murder{/sc} {sc}assassinate{/sc} {sc}dispatch{/sc} {sc}execute{/sc} mean to deprive of life. {sc}kill{/sc} merely states the fact of death caused by an agency in any manner.
{sc}slay{/sc} is a chiefly literary term implying deliberateness and violence but not necessarily motive.
{sc}murder{/sc} specifically implies stealth and motive and premeditation and therefore full moral responsibility.
{sc}assassinate{/sc} applies to deliberate killing openly or secretly often for political motives.
{sc}dispatch{/sc} stresses quickness and directness in putting to death.
{sc}execute{/sc} stresses putting to death as a legal penalty.

pt: In North American speech {it}kilometer{/it} is most often pronounced with primary stress on the second syllable. This pronunciation is also heard frequently in British speech. Those who object to second syllable stress say that the first syllable should be stressed in accord with the stress patterns of {it}centimeter, millimeter{/it}, etc. However, the pronunciation of {it}kilometer{/it} does not parallel that of other metric compounds. From 1828 to 1841 Noah Webster indicated only second syllable stress, and his successor added a first syllable stress variant in the first Merriam-Webster dictionary of 1847. Thus, both pronunciations are venerable. Most scientists use second syllable stress, although first syllable stress seems to occur with a higher rate of frequency among scientists than among nonscientists.

et: Middle English {it}kynrede{/it} "family, lineage, blood relations, kinship, nation," going back to late Old English {it}cynrǣden{/it} "kinship" (attested once as {it}kynrædan,{/it} accusative or dative), from {it}cynn{/it} "progeny, {et_link|kin:1|kin:1}" + {it}-rǣden,{/it} suffixal use of {it}rǣden{/it} "condition, stipulation," derivative (in {it}-enn-,{/it} feminine noun suffix, going back to {it}*inj-{/it}) probably from the base of {it}gerǣde{/it} "prepared, ready," {it}gerād{/it} "conditioned, disposed" {ma}{mat|ready:1|}{/ma}

The noun {it}rǣden,{/it} also attested in the senses "rule, direction" and "estimation," has been taken as a derivative of the verb {it}rǣdan{/it} "to advise, deliberate, direct," etc. (see {et_link|read:1|read:1}), though these usages may reflect partial merger with {it}rǣding,{/it} the verbal noun of {it}rǣdan.{/it} In general, the outcomes of Germanic {it}*raidja-{/it} and {it}*rēd-{/it} can be difficult to separate in Old English.

dt: {bc}a sweet ring-shaped cake traditionally with a symbolic bean or figurine of the infant Jesus inside that is served from the {d_link|Epiphany|epiphany} to {d_link|Shrove Tuesday|Shrove Tuesday}

dt.t: Of course, no one does {wi}king cake{/wi} quite like New Orleans. It's decorated in the colors of Mardi Gras—purple (to represent justice), green (faith) and gold (power)—as chosen by one of the city's first Mardi Gras organizations, or krewes. A token or trinket—usually a plastic baby symbolizing the infant Jesus—is hidden inside. Whoever finds the baby may be crowned king or queen of the party; more important, that person is responsible for bringing the cake to the next gathering.

shortdef: a sweet ring-shaped cake traditionally with a symbolic bean or figurine of the infant Jesus inside that is served from the Epiphany to Shrove Tuesday

The horseshoe crab is often said to have five pairs of legs since the first pair is greatly reduced in size and used mainly for feeding. All the legs of the horseshoe crab end in claws except for the last pair of legs which have leaflike expansions used mainly for pushing.

pt: {sc}gift{/sc} {sc}faculty{/sc} {sc}aptitude{/sc} {sc}bent{/sc} {sc}talent{/sc} {sc}genius{/sc} {sc}knack{/sc} mean a special ability for doing something. {sc}gift{/sc} often implies special favor by God or nature.
{sc}faculty{/sc} applies to an innate or less often acquired ability for a particular accomplishment or function.
{sc}aptitude{/sc} implies a natural liking for some activity and the likelihood of success in it.
{sc}bent{/sc} is nearly equal to {sc}aptitude{/sc} but it stresses inclination perhaps more than specific ability.
{sc}talent{/sc} suggests a marked natural ability that needs to be developed.
{sc}knack{/sc} implies a comparatively minor but special ability making for ease and dexterity in performance.

shortdef: a special ready capacity that is hard to analyze or teach

dt: {bc}a thick flat triangular movable bone that forms the anterior point of the knee and protects the front of the joint {bc}{sx|patella||}

dt.t: … [Richard] Steadman did arthroscopic surgery on both knees, taking out cartilage, and adjusting synovial plica, the bands of thickened tissue that line the joint behind the {wi}kneecaps{/wi} …
Many people who play basketball, volleyball, or soccer are all too familiar with patellar tendinitis, an inflammation of the large tendon connecting the {wi}kneecap{/wi} to the upper tibia.
The stifle joint of a horse corresponds to the human knee. It has a patella, or {wi}kneecap{/wi}, at the front of the joint.

shortdef: a thick flat triangular movable bone that forms the anterior point of the knee and protects the front of the joint : patella

dt: {bc}to shoot or otherwise maim or cripple the knee of (someone)

dt.t: He was shot in both knees, deliberately maimed—{ldquo}{wi}kneecapped{/wi},{rdquo} in local parlance.

… punishing petty crooks and unruly juveniles by {wi}kneecapping{/wi} them, sometimes with bullets, sometimes with a … power drill. The degree of crippling one receives is supposed to be a reflection of the gravity of one's crime.

… hearing from people who grasp their brows in dire concern over whether the President is now too damaged to carry on—this from people who have been doing their … best to {wi}kneecap{/wi} the man for years.
This 66-yard scoring drive Smith engineered late in the first half … basically {wi}kneecapped{/wi} the home team.
The decision to liquidate $25 million worth of the band's Live Nation stock last year nearly {wi}kneecapped{/wi} the company …

shortdef: to shoot or otherwise maim or cripple the knee of (someone) — often used figuratively

dt: {bc}a thick flat triangular movable bone that forms the anterior point of the knee and protects the front of the joint {bc}{sx|kneecap||}

dt.t: … the quadriceps are attached at the anterior and anterior lateral aspect of the {wi}patella{/wi} and are extensors of the knee joint.
… a few horses suffer from a slipping of the {wi}patella{/wi}—the little bone on the front of the stifle that is similar to the human kneecap—locking the joint so that it cannot flex properly.

The human knee is specialized for walking upright too: to compensate for the thighbone's being at an angle, there's a lump, or groove, at the end of the femur that prevents the {wi}patella{/wi} from sliding off the joint.

aq.auth: Michael D. Lemonick and Andrea Dorfman

dt: {bc}a formulaic joke that begins with the words {ldquo}Knock knock{rdquo} in imitation of someone knocking on a door

The standard pattern of a knock-knock joke calls for a response of {ldquo}Who's there?{rdquo}, a cryptic reply identifying the knocker, a further response repeating the name of the knocker followed by {ldquo}who?{rdquo}, and a final joking reply typically featuring a pun or play on words.

dt.t: William Cole … is a perpetrator of, and authority on, the {wi}knock-knock joke{/wi}. {ldquo}{wi}Knock-knock jokes{/wi} are basically puns, that's all, and you've got to have a feel for the ludicrous,{rdquo} he says. …. he considers the following to be his best creation: {ldquo}Knock knock.{rdquo} Who's there? {ldquo}Amaryllis.{rdquo} Amaryllis who? {ldquo}Amaryllis state agent. Wanna buy a house?{rdquo}

Big Bird to audience: {ldquo}You're having fun, right? Okay, let's do a {wi}knock-knock joke{/wi}. Knock knock.{rdquo} Audience: {ldquo}Who's there?{rdquo} BB: {ldquo}Ya.{rdquo} Audience: {ldquo}Ya who?{rdquo} BB: {ldquo}See, I told you you were having fun.{rdquo} Groan if you like, but it's a hoot to a 4-year-old.

shortdef: a formulaic joke that begins with the words "Knock knock" in imitation of someone knocking on a door

pt: {sc}simple{/sc} {sc}foolish{/sc} {sc}silly{/sc} {sc}fatuous{/sc} {sc}asinine{/sc} mean actually or apparently deficient in intelligence. {sc}simple{/sc} implies a degree of intelligence inadequate to cope with anything complex or involving mental effort.

pt.t: considered people {it}simple{/it} who had trouble with computers

pt: {sc}foolish{/sc} implies the character of being or seeming unable to use judgment, discretion, or good sense.
{sc}silly{/sc} suggests failure to act as a rational being especially by ridiculous behavior.
{sc}fatuous{/sc} implies foolishness, inanity, and disregard of reality.
{sc}asinine{/sc} suggests utter and contemptible failure to use normal rationality or perception.

pt: {sc}complex{/sc} {sc}complicated{/sc} {sc}intricate{/sc} {sc}involved{/sc} {sc}knotty{/sc} mean having confusingly interrelated parts. {sc}complex{/sc} suggests the unavoidable result of a necessary combining and does not imply a fault or failure.
{sc}complicated{/sc} applies to what offers great difficulty in understanding, solving, or explaining.
{sc}intricate{/sc} suggests such interlacing of parts as to make it nearly impossible to follow or grasp them separately.
{sc}involved{/sc} implies extreme complication and often disorder.
{sc}knotty{/sc} suggests complication and entanglement that make solution or understanding improbable.

shortdef: marked by or full of knots; especially : so full of difficulties and complications as to be likely to defy solution

pt: {sc}complex{/sc} {sc}complicated{/sc} {sc}intricate{/sc} {sc}involved{/sc} {sc}knotty{/sc} mean having confusingly interrelated parts. {sc}complex{/sc} suggests the unavoidable result of a necessary combining and does not imply a fault or failure.
{sc}complicated{/sc} applies to what offers great difficulty in understanding, solving, or explaining.
{sc}intricate{/sc} suggests such interlacing of parts as to make it nearly impossible to follow or grasp them separately.
{sc}involved{/sc} implies extreme complication and often disorder.
{sc}knotty{/sc} suggests complication and entanglement that make solution or understanding improbable.

dt: often used to describe something likened to kryptonite in causing someone's weakness, failure, etc.

dt.t: In his career Thome has hit less than .240 against lefties. Lefthanded power pitching is Thome's {wi}Kryptonite{/wi} …
Ironic people always dissolve when confronted with earnestness, it's their {wi}kryptonite{/wi}.

{ldquo}Thin people know they need to either limit exposure to certain foods that trigger appetite or limit the quantity or frequency of those foods,{rdquo} says Gullo, whose personal {wi}kryptonite{/wi} is pizza.
Effortlessly good-looking, he was also a talented writer—that combo was my {wi}kryptonite{/wi}.

pt: Some commentators hold that since {it}kudos{/it} is a singular word it cannot be used as a plural and that the word {it}kudo{/it} is impossible. But {it}kudo{/it} does exist; it is simply one of the most recent words created by back-formation from another word misunderstood as a plural. {it}Kudos{/it} was introduced into English in the 19th century; it was used in contexts where a reader unfamiliar with Greek could not be sure whether it was singular or plural. By the 1920s it began to appear as a plural, and about 25 years later {it}kudo{/it} began to appear. It may have begun as a misunderstanding, but then so did {it}cherry{/it} and {it}pea.{/it}

pt: Some commentators hold that since {it}kudos{/it} is a singular word it cannot be used as a plural and that the word {it}kudo{/it} is impossible. But {it}kudo{/it} does exist; it is simply one of the most recent words created by back-formation from another word misunderstood as a plural. {it}Kudos{/it} was introduced into English in the 19th century; it was used in contexts where a reader unfamiliar with Greek could not be sure whether it was singular or plural. By the 1920s it began to appear as a plural, and about 25 years later {it}kudo{/it} began to appear. It may have begun as a misunderstanding, but then so did {it}cherry{/it} and {it}pea.{/it}
